issue.title: Crash when hitting a 404 during `delete_object()` call
issue.body:
### Version & Environment

Redpanda version: (use `rpk version`): v22.3.4

<!--

Please also give versions of other components:
- Operating System (e.g. from `/etc/os-release`):
- Any Kafka client libraries in use (e.g. rdkafka, franz-go)
- Docker (use `docker info`):
- Kubernetes (use `kubectl version`):

Include link to test results for automated test failures

-->

### What went wrong?

We triggered an assert failure because S3 returned a 404:

```
ERROR 2022-12-02 21:05:33,803 [shard 5] assert - Assert failure: (/var/lib/buildkite-agent/builds/buildkite-amd64-xfs-builders-i-04413b3a03dfa992b-1/redpanda/redpanda/src/v/cloud_storage/remote.cc:685) 'false' Unexpected NoSuchKey error response from DeleteObject {"b0000000/meta/kafka/test/topic_manifest.json"}
```

It seems like we don't expect `NoSuchKey` errors when calling `delete_object()`. [Docs](https://awscli.amazonaws.com/v2/documentation/api/latest/reference/s3api/delete-objects.html#output) for the python S3 client mention `NoSuchFound`, though the consistency semantics of our S3 retries are a bit unclear to me.

Another thought is that the replica was deleted before it could even upload to S3.

<!--
  Describe the unexpected behavior
-->

### What should have happened instead?

Assuming this is a legitimate state, we should avoid crashing.
<!--
  Describe what you wanted to happen.
-->

### How to reproduce the issue?

1.
2.
3.

### Additional information

Logs
[redpanda_404_crash.txt](https://github.com/redpanda-data/redpanda/files/10144789/redpanda_404_crash.txt)

Please attach any relevant logs, backtraces, or metric charts.

comment.body:
Let’s also please make sure we gracefully handle all potential errors that might crash the process: 
* S3: https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AmazonS3/latest/API/ErrorResponses.html#ErrorCodeList
* GCS: https://cloud.google.com/storage/docs/troubleshooting#error_codes

issue.title: Structured logging

comment.body:
> @c4milo did you have some thoughts around structured logging and what the goals are? I think we discussed this in the context of Grafana Cloud logging and I'm not sure if this is broader initiative than that.

@dotnwat, I completely miss this message, apologies. The context of that request came up after many V1 incidents, we wanted to aggregate and categorize different types of errors to create Grafana panels and alerts for them. As for the log format, it can be either key=value pairs or JSON.

issue.title: Destroy operations do not seem to be idempotent
issue.body:
If the namespace doesn't exist, I would expect the destroy operation to be fully idempotent and carry on. The current behavior fails with ` namespaces "monitoring" not found`

### Terraform Version, Provider Version and Kubernetes Version
<!--- Run `terraform -v` to show the version. If you are not running the latest version of Terraform, please upgrade because your issue may have already been fixed. --->
```
Terraform version: v1.2.5
Kubernetes provider version: 2.13.1
Kubernetes version: 1.21 (EKS)
```

### References
* https://hashicorp.github.io/terraform-provider-aws/running-and-writing-acceptance-tests/#disappears-acceptance-tests

### Community Note
<!--- Please keep this note for the community --->
* Please vote on this issue by adding a 👍 [reaction](https://blog.github.com/2016-03-10-add-reactions-to-pull-requests-issues-and-comments/) to the original issue to help the community and maintainers prioritize this request
* If you are interested in working on this issue or have submitted a pull request, please leave a comment

comment.body: FWIW, this is potentially also caused by lack of idempotency in the provider: https://github.com/hashicorp/terraform-provider-kubernetes/issues/1455. My team ran into it today.

commits.message: Update README to account for new API

Fix error reporting for reader

since it was never making out of the local scope.

payload.description: Go package to natively decompress and unarchive tar.gz, tar.bzip2, tar.xz, zip and tar files.

commits.message:
Simplify API

To reduce confusion regarding destination path passed as argument
versus returned, and prevent accidental misuse. The destination
path is now always required.

issue.title: Destroy operations are not idempotent

labels.name: waiting-response
labels.description: An issue/pull request is waiting for a response from the community

labels.name: waiting for reproduction
labels.description: unable to reproduce issue without further information

issue.body:
### Terraform Version

```shell
v1.2.8
```


### Terraform Configuration Files

any resource or data source from at least the kubernetes or AWS provider. 

### Debug Output

...

### Expected Behavior

Destroy operations should be idempotent for data sources and resources alike. Otherwise, they are non-deterministic altogether. I started noticing the issue with some providers such as with data sources in the AWS providers and regular resources with the Kubernetes providers. After thinking for a while and reporting the issues on the specific providers' repos, I decided to raise it up in core because this pattern seems to be prevalent and the Terraform Plugin SDK nor the Terraform Framework SDK seem to encourage or facilitate testing for idempotent destroy operations. 

### Actual Behavior

destroy operations fail when remote resources do not exist. See: https://github.com/hashicorp/terraform-provider-kubernetes/issues/1822 and https://github.com/hashicorp/terraform-provider-aws/issues/26228 

### Steps to Reproduce

1. terraform init
2. terraform apply 
3. manually delete remote resource either through AWS Console/CLI/API or GCP Console/CLI/API.
4. terraform destroy

### Additional Context

_No response_

### References

* https://github.com/hashicorp/terraform-provider-aws/issues/26228
* https://github.com/hashicorp/terraform-provider-kubernetes/issues/1822
* https://github.com/hashicorp/terraform/pull/27408

comment.body:
@bflad won me to it 🥇. 
 
@jbardin, thanks for such a prompt answer. I also was leaning towards kicking this ball to the providers but then I thought that this issue really effects the Terraform brand because the user experience ends up being inconsistent. It would be ideal if Terraform core somehow helps providers to be fully idempotent, either by making it easier or possible for providers to test idempotent destroy operations. Agreed with @bflad on that maybe the best venue for this discussion is the plugin framework SDK.

### Community Note

comment.body: @alexsomesan, any guidance on how one would go about testing idempotent destroys? The current terraform-plugin-sdk seems to be mostly designed to test the full lifecycle, it is not very clear how to tell it to run destroy twice.

comment.body: To give more context, this is not only a UX issue but a reliability issue when Terraform is used as a core tool to orchestrate infrastructure for managed services such as Managed Consuls, Managed Vaults, Managed nameyourservice.

@bflad won me to it 🥇. 
 
@jbardin, thanks for such a prompt answer. I also was leaning towards kicking this ball to the providers but then I thought that this issue really effects the Terraform brand because the user experience ends up being inconsistent. It would be ideal if Terraform core somehow helps providers to be fully idempotent, either by making it easier or possible for providers to test idempotent destroy operations. Agreed with @bflad on that maybe the best venue for this discussion is the plugin framework SDK.

issue.title: Destroy operations are not idempotent
issue.body:
### Terraform Version

```shell
v1.2.8
```


### Terraform Configuration Files

any resource or data source from at least the kubernetes or AWS provider. 

### Debug Output

...

### Expected Behavior

Destroy operations should be idempotent for data sources and resources alike. Otherwise, they are non-deterministic altogether. I started noticing the issue with some providers such as with data sources in the AWS providers and regular resources with the Kubernetes providers. After thinking for a while and reporting the issues on the specific providers' repos, I decided to raise it up in core because this pattern seems to be prevalent and the Terraform Plugin SDK nor the Terraform Framework SDK seem to encourage or facilitate testing for idempotent destroy operations. 

### Actual Behavior

destroy operations fail when remote resources do not exist. See: https://github.com/hashicorp/terraform-provider-kubernetes/issues/1822 and https://github.com/hashicorp/terraform-provider-aws/issues/26228 

### Steps to Reproduce

1. terraform init
2. terraform apply 
3. manually delete remote resource either through AWS Console/CLI or GCP Console/CLI.
4. terraform destroy

### Additional Context

_No response_

### References

* https://github.com/hashicorp/terraform-provider-aws/issues/26228
* https://github.com/hashicorp/terraform-provider-kubernetes/issues/1822
* https://github.com/hashicorp/terraform/pull/27408

issue.title: Destroy operations do not seem to be idempotent
issue.body:
If the namespace doesn't exist, I would expect the destroy operation to be fully idempotent and carry on. The current behavior fails with ` namespaces "monitoring" not found`

### Terraform Version, Provider Version and Kubernetes Version
<!--- Run `terraform -v` to show the version. If you are not running the latest version of Terraform, please upgrade because your issue may have already been fixed. --->
```
Terraform version: v1.2.5
Kubernetes provider version: 2.13.1
Kubernetes version: 1.21 (EKS)
```

### Community Note
<!--- Please keep this note for the community --->
* Please vote on this issue by adding a 👍 [reaction](https://blog.github.com/2016-03-10-add-reactions-to-pull-requests-issues-and-comments/) to the original issue to help the community and maintainers prioritize this request
* If you are interested in working on this issue or have submitted a pull request, please leave a comment

comment.body: @alexsomesan, any guidance on how one would go about testing idempotent destroys? The current terraform-plugin-sdk seems to be mostly designed to test the full lifecycle, it is not very clear how to tell it to run destroy twice.

comment.body: To give more context, this is not only a UX issue but a reliability issue when Terraform is used as a core tool to orchestrate infrastructure for managed services such as Managed Consuls, Managed Vaults, Managed nameyourservice.
